title: Fabulous food chains

options.text: It is stored in the animal's body.

options.label: D
options.text: Because hair is too short to feel pain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of nerves in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To carry messages between different parts of the body.

options.label: B
options.text: To help us see and hear.

options.label: C
options.text: To help us smell and taste.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when something touches our skin?

options.label: A
options.text: It activates the nerves in our skin.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes our skin feel warm or cold.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes our skin feel smooth or rough.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes our skin feel nothing.

multiple-choice.question: How do nerves send messages to our brain?

options.label: B
options.text: Through a big bundle of nerves in our back.

options.label: C
options.text: Through a network of nerves in our body.

options.label: D
options.text: Through a special type of energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when our brain decodes the messages from our nerves?
Why can't we feel pain when we touch our hair?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our hair is too short.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our hair is too thick.

options.label: C
options.text: Because there are no nerves inside our hair.

options.label: D
options.text: Because our hair is too soft.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between our sense of touch and our brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Our sense of touch is controlled by our brain.

options.label: B
options.text: Our sense of touch is separate from our brain.

options.label: C
options.text: Our sense of touch is a result of our brain's processing.

options.label: D
options.text: Our sense of touch is not related to our brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between our sense of touch and our sense of sight?

options.label: A
options.text: Our sense of touch is faster than our sense of sight.

options.label: B
options.text: Our sense of touch is slower than our sense of sight.

options.label: C
options.text: Our sense of touch is a result of our brain's processing, while our sense of sight is a direct result of light entering our eyes.

options.label: D
options.text: Our sense of touch is a direct result of light entering our eyes.

multiple-choice.question: Why do fingernails and toenails not feel pain when they are cut?

options.label: C
options.text: Because there are no nerves inside them.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why haircuts don't hurt?

options.label: A
options.text: Because hair is made of a hard, non-sensitive material.

options.label: B
options.text: Because hair has a thick layer of skin around it.

options.label: C
options.text: Because hair doesn't have nerves inside it.

options.label: D
options.text: Because hair is too short to feel pain.

title: Why is my leg asleep?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of numbness in the arms and legs?

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced blood flow due to pressure

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the blood vessels in the affected area when the body is in a fixed position?

options.label: A
options.text: They expand to allow for increased blood flow

multiple-choice.question: What is the temporary sensation felt when the nerves wake up after being compressed?

options.label: B
options.text: Tingling or prickly sensation (pins and needles)

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended course of action if you experience pins and needles?

options.label: A
options.text: Apply pressure to the affected area

options.label: B
options.text: Shake the affected arm or leg to improve blood flow

options.label: C
options.text: Take a break and move around

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of nerves in the body?

options.label: C
options.text: To transmit sensory information to the brain

multiple-choice.question: Why do nerves require adequate blood flow to function properly?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they need oxygen to function

options.label: B
options.text: Because they need nutrients to function

options.label: C
options.text: Because they require energy to transmit signals

options.label: D
options.text: Because they need to transmit signals to the brain

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body if you sit or lean in one position for too long?

options.label: A
options.text: You will experience numbness in the affected area

options.label: B
options.text: You will experience pain in the affected area

options.label: C
options.text: You will experience tingling or prickly sensation (pins and needles)

options.label: D
options.text: You will experience all of the above

multiple-choice.question: How long does it usually take for the prickling sensation to resolve on its own?
What can you do to prevent pins and needles?

options.label: A
options.text: Take regular breaks to move around

options.label: B
options.text: Apply pressure to the affected area

options.label: C
options.text: Stay in the same position for extended periods

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid using your arms and legs

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended action to take if you get pins and needles?

options.label: A
options.text: Apply pressure to the affected area

options.label: B
options.text: Shake the affected arm or leg to improve blood flow

options.label: C
options.text: Take a break and move around

options.label: B
options.text: Add "es" to the end of the word

options.label: C
options.text: Add "s" or "es" depending on the sound

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Add "es" or "s" depending on the sound

options.text: Add "s" to the end of the word

options.label: C
options.text: Add "es" or "s" depending on the sound

title: Closed and open syllables | Learn to read

multiple-choice.question: What is the characteristic of a vowel sound in an open syllable?

options.label: A
options.text: The vowel makes a short sound.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel says its letter name.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following words is an example of a closed syllable?
What happens to the vowel sound in a closed syllable?

options.label: D
options.text: It changes to a different letter.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following words is an example of an open syllable?
What is the difference between an open and a closed syllable?

options.label: A
options.text: An open syllable has a vowel sound that is longer, while a closed syllable has a vowel sound that is shorter.

options.label: B
options.text: An open syllable has a vowel sound that is shorter, while a closed syllable has a vowel sound that is longer.

options.label: C
options.text: An open syllable has a vowel sound that is silent, while a closed syllable has a vowel sound that is pronounced.

options.label: D
options.text: An open syllable has a vowel sound that is pronounced, while a closed syllable has a vowel sound that is silent.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following words is an example of a word with an open syllable?
What happens to the vowel sound in an open syllable?
Which of the following words is an example of a word with a closed syllable?
Why does the vowel sound become shorter in a closed syllable?

options.label: C
options.text: Because the vowel makes a short sound.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key takeaway from the concept of open and closed syllables?

options.label: A
options.text: The vowel sound is always longer in an open syllable.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel sound is always shorter in a closed syllable.

options.label: C
options.text: The vowel sound says its letter name in an open syllable and makes a short sound in a closed syllable.

options.label: D
options.text: The vowel sound is always silent in both open and closed syllables.

title: Human, capital & natural resources for kids | Types of resources

multiple-choice.question: What are the three main types of resources?

options.label: B
options.text: Human resources, capital resources, and natural resources

options.label: A
options.text: Goods that are made and used to provide a service

options.label: C
options.text: Things that are found on earth and can be used by people

options.label: D
options.text: Services that someone does for you

options.text: Goods that are made and used to provide a service

options.label: C
